results.title: Craftsmen young and old
results.brief_description: A screen magazine containing three items: “Man who makes monsters” Dinosaurs, towering reptiles and other prehistoric creatures, all made of concrete by John Kanerva, turn Calgary Park into a primeval zoo; “All the family carves” Visit to the home workshop of Andre Bourgault, famous French-Canadian sculptor, whose children are learning his craft; “Last of the totem makers” Chief Mango Martin and his son preserve in their carving of totem poles, a unique art of Canada’s Pacific coast Indians.

results.title: Craftsmart: christmas special
results.creator_credit: Phillip Harris, Kingwest Productions and Lennox Television Productions
results.brief_description: Great Australian Christmas decoration ideas, with Lena Williams who gives step by step instructions to make low cost, easy and highly decorative handicrafts including a traditional Christmas wreath and an Australian Christmas table setting complete with bread basket, napkins, salt and pepper shakers and an Australian centrepiece and bon bons.

results.title: Crafts of my province = Artisans de nouveau Brunswick [French language]
results.creator_credit: Marcel Martin, Peter Jones and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A documentary on Canadian artisans from New Brunswick revolving around a sculptress and her husband who is a potter. Shows how they decorate, glaze and fire the pottery and each year open their house as a showroom to lovers of art. We meet their friends who are silversmiths and get inspiration from the sea and rocks and use stones to make jewellery. Also shows wool being dyed and woven into cloth for sale to the USA and overseas.

results.title: Crafts of My Province
results.creator_credit: Kirk Jones, Douglas Jackson, Peter Jones and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A film visit to New Brunswick craftsmen, such as the potters Kjeld and Erica Deichmann of Sussex, N.B., who demonstrate all stages, from potter’s wheel to kiln. Shown also are the hand-looming of woolens and the designing of jewelry from local stones and silver.

results.title: Crafts in Australia
results.creator_credit: Stafford Garner, Australia Council and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: This is a semi-promotional film made for the Crafts Council of Australia. Shows Australian craftsmen and women and their ideas, motivation and life style. Mirka Mora briefly features.

results.title: Craft in the cowshed
results.creator_credit: Jack Rogers, Jack S. Allan and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the correct method of milking cows to obtain the maximum yield of milk, and the importance of keeping the milking equipment clean.

results.title: Cradle To The Grave (1994)
results.brief_description: Released in 1994, Cradle To The Grave was the music video for rap group Thug Life’s latest single. It commented on racial politics and incarceration in the America.

constellations_other.name: Confronting injustice on-screen
constellations_other.description: The Black Lives Matter movement and the treatment of African Americans at the hands of authorities is explored in this Constellation that connects hip-hop, the Civil Rights Movement and representation in Hollywood.

results.title: Cracking the stone age code
results.creator_credit: David Collison, Paul Johnstone and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: Examines the work of Alexander Thom, former professor of engineering science at Oxford, whose investigations into stone circles and standing circles of Britain threaten to upset prehistoric knowledge. We see him at work in Scotland, and then go to Britain to see how his findings apply there.
results.description: Examines the work of Alexander Thom, former professor of engineering science at Oxford, whose investigations into stone circles and standing circles of Britain threaten to upset prehistoric knowledge. results.title: Cracking the egg
results.brief_description: A comprehensive look at eggs. Considers the variations in size shape, texture and structure. Notes the origins of the egg, how it forms, the incubation differences by parent birds, hatching and the fate of the residual shell. Also touches on the so called bionic egg, egg collecting, the domestication of wildfowl, the egg’s place in folklore, its uses in the culinary arts, its influence in the decorative arts, the egg marketing industry, Easter eggs and artificial eggs.

results.title: Crackerjack
results.creator_credit: Paul Moloney, Stephen Luby, Mick Molloy, A Million Monkeys, Macquarie Film Corporation and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: In this laconic Australian comedy an immature thirty-something male discovers something of life when he becomes involved with an ailing local lawn bowls club under threat of closure at the hands of mercenary developers. Mick Molloy (who co-wrote the film with brother Richard) plays Jack, a shabby and exploitative ill-mannered oaf, whose interest in being a member of the club begins and ends with the cheap inner-city parking it provides. When the elderly members of the club call upon him to play the game or forfeit his membership, Jack soon learns lessons in humility, a love of the game and respect for his elderly companions. With a broad comic tone, Australian idiosyncrasies (albeit familiar ones) - excessive swearing, drinking, smoking and jokes about the sexuality of octogenarians - abound. The gender roles are well defined; women in charge of baking, whilst mateship and honour are the ideals to which men aspire. Like “The Castle” (Rob Sitch, 1997) this film embraces the classic David versus Goliath structure, as the morally sound little man faces an evil corporate developer seeking to undermine a certain spirit and camaraderie of society. Melbourne comedian Judith Lucy plays Nance, a local reporter who becomes concerned for the future of the club and forms a romantic attachment to Jack. Also stars Samuel Johnson.
